channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bangladesh Attack Suggests Shift by ISIS as It Loses Territory
item.media:description: Relatives mourn victims killed in the siege. At least 30 people were wounded.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility after gunmen detonated explosives and killed 20 hostages at a restaurant in Dhaka, the capital.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, GEETA ANAND and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Austria’s Far Right Presents the E.U. With a New Test at the Polls
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer of the Freedom Party, left, and Alexander Van der Bellen, a former leader of the Green Party. Mr. Hofer lost to Mr. Van der Bellen in a May 22 vote.
item.description: A new presidential election in Austria could well serve as a referendum on the central tenets, roles and responsibilities of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Elie Wiesel, Auschwitz Survivor and Nobel Peace Prize Winner, Dies at 87
item.media:description: Elie Wiesel, center, with his wife, Marion; their son, Shlomo Elisha; and Egil Aarvik, the chairman of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, after receiving the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986.
item.description: Mr. Wiesel, the author of “Night,” seared the memory of the Holocaust on the world’s conscience.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH BERGER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Bats Aside Younger Generation’s European Identity
item.media:description: Kim Seele, left, and Carolina Leersch on their balcony in Berlin. While studying in Stockholm, they befriended Antoine Guéry, a Frenchman. It is an example of how easily young Europeans have built relationships regardless of borders.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Young adults are grappling with what Britain’s vote to leave the European Union will mean for a way of life in which it’s normal to grow up in one country, study in another and work in a third.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: ISIS Said to Target Foreigners in Bangladesh Attack
item.media:description: Hasnat Karim, left, who was a hostage at the Holey Artisan Bakery, climbed into a car on Saturday with his wife, Sharmin Karim, after being rescued.
item.description: In an act that killed nine Italians and seven Japanese citizens, assailants wrenched a cafe’s customers from a space of tolerance and cultural exchange to one of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Taking Down Politicians for Decades, and Rising in India’s Government
item.media:description: “My critics began saying I was a chauvinist, nationalist, mad nationalist.” SUBRAMANIAN SWAMY
item.description: Subramanian Swamy is arguably the most vicious infighter in the country’s politics, but the question is whether the prime minister can keep him on a tight enough leash.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Citing Safety, Bookseller Pulls Out of Hong Kong Pro-Democracy March
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee. The bookstore where he worked in Hong Kong sold gossipy books about China’s leadership.
item.description: Lam Wing-kee had indicated that he had been followed over the previous two days by people he did not recognize, an official said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Israel Imposes Restrictions on Palestinians in West Bank After Attacks
item.media:description: Israeli security forces investigated after an attack on a family driving near Hebron on Friday.
item.description: Israel said that it would prevent all Palestinian movement in the southern West Bank and withhold some crucial tax revenues from the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Cockpit Recordings Retrieved in EgyptAir Flight 804 Investigation
item.description: Investigators will analyze the recordings to determine what caused the plane to crash and how the pilots assessed and responded to the emergency.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: U.S. Offers to Increase Military Aid to Israel
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a press conference on Tuesday.
item.description: The proposal, in a shift, would require the Israelis to use the tens of billions of dollars they receive to buy United States-made goods and services.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 3 Kenyans Last Seen at Police Station Are Found Dead
item.media:description: Lawyers rallied at Kenya’s Supreme Court in Nairobi on Wednesday to press the government’s investigation into the disappearance of three men — a lawyer, a client and a taxi driver.
item.description: The bodies of a lawyer, his last known client and a taxi driver were discovered after their disappearance last week unsettled human rights activists.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Reaction to Canada’s Warm Welcome for Syrian Refugees
item.description: Responses to a Times article on Canadians’ acceptance of refugee families ranged from “beautiful” to “a ticking time bomb.” What do you think?
item.dc:creator: ARI ISAACMAN BEVACQUA

item.title: An Alaskan Village Where Grizzlies Roam and Canada Rules (if Anyone Does)
item.media:description: A Canadian man working on a dock in Stewart, British Columbia. The town is in the valley behind him. Stewart has an unusual fellowship with its American neighbor, Hyder, Alaska, which relies on many services from across the border, including electricity, and also uses Canadian currency.
item.description: The people of Hyder, Alaska, have created a world apart from much of the United States, largely fending for themselves. But they rely on their British Columbian neighbors for many things.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Mob Burns Down Mosque in Myanmar; U.N Urges Action on Attacks
item.media:description: Yanghee Lee, the United Nations’ special human rights envoy to Myanmar, expressed concern over attacks on religious properties.
item.description: The attack was the second of its kind in just over a week, and came on the same day the U.N. urged the government to clamp down on violence against Muslims.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Journal: ‘Brexit’ Vote Gave Me a Harsh, Belated Wake-Up Call
item.media:description: Family photos of Francesca Barber during her upbringing in Europe. Clockwise from top left: in Saint-Luc, Switzerland, in 1994; behind her father and brother in Paris in 1993; fourth from the left in Apeldoorn, the Netherlands, in 1997; and in Siena, Italy, in 1995.
item.description: Born in Washington, the author grew up in Europe and came to appreciate the sense of feeling so connected to other Europeans. Now she is trying to make sense of what happened.
item.dc:creator: FRANCESCA BARBER

item.title: Losses in Australia Election Could Threaten Governing Coalition
item.media:description: Bill Shorten, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, which picked up several seats in Parliament, in Melbourne on Saturday.
item.description: The conservative Liberal National majority could lose more than 10 seats in Parliament, according to early election returns on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: The Interpreter: After ‘Brexit,’ Some in E.U. Push Military Unity, but Voters Focus on Threats Within
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling outside the European Commission in Brussels on Wednesday. As the Continent has faced external crises, states have responded by working through the larger union.
item.description: France and Germany have a chance to pursue a long-held goal of an integrated European military, but such a move would do little to address terrorism.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Britons Put Rancor Aside to Commemorate the Battle of the Somme
item.media:description: Young people placed wreaths on graves at the Commonwealth cemetery in Thiepval, France, to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the the Battle of the Somme in World War I.
item.description: The nation turned away from discord over the vote to leave the European Union to mark the 100th anniversary of the bloody World War I battle.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: U.S. Reveals Death Toll From Airstrikes Outside War Zones
item.media:description: President Obama in the Oval Office of the White House on Friday.
item.description: About 64 to 116 civilians and about 2,500 members of terrorist groups have died in American airstrikes, the Obama administration said, hundreds lower than independent estimates.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and SCOTT SHANE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Faulting Both Israelis and Palestinians, Report Aims to Revive Peace Talks
item.media:description: Yishuv Hadaat, a Jewish settlement outpost in the West Bank, in May.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: The Middle East Quartet urged Israel to change its settlement policies and Palestinian groups to stop glorifying attacks.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: German Sentenced to 14 Years for Stabbing Mayoral Candidate in Cologne
item.media:description: Henriette Reker campaigning for the mayoral election in Cologne, Germany, on Oct. 16, a day before she was stabbed. A man, identified only as Frank S., was found guilty on Friday of attempted murder.
item.media:credit: Oliver Berg/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Judge Barbara Havliza said the attack at a campaign rally for Henriette Reker was an attempt “to create a climate of fear” at a time of large migration into the country.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: No Charisma, No Glamour: Michael Gove Makes His Case to Lead Britain
item.media:description: Theresa May, at a regatta in Henley, England, on Friday, is the favorite of five candidates seeking to be prime minister.
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The British justice secretary, one of the leaders of the Leave campaign, argued that he best represented the mood of the party and the country.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Mosha, Thai Elephant Wounded by Land Mine, Gets New Prosthetic Limb
item.media:description: Mosha had her new prosthetic leg fitted in Lampang, Thailand, on Wednesday.
item.description: She is one of more than a dozen elephants who have been hurt near the border with Myanmar, where rebels have been fighting for decades.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Friends of the Asian Elephant Foundation

item.title: Chinese Court Postpones Trial of Activist, Angering Supporters
item.media:description: Chen Yunfei, an artist and activist, has been charged with “picking quarrels and provoking trouble,” a catchall crime that the Chinese authorities have used frequently in recent years to silence dissent.
item.description: The court did not give the artist and liberal political activist, Chen Yunfei, a new date for the trial or explain the delay, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Battle of the Somme; Tories Step Up as Boris Johnson Exits
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain attended an evening service in London to honor the centenary of the Battle of the Somme on Thursday.
item.media:credit: British Ministry of Defence/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The political crisis was temporarily set aside as leaders commemorated the Battle of the Somme, but candidates for prime minister are laying groundwork.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: Hindu Priest in Bangladesh Is Hacked to Death
item.description: The priest is the fourth Hindu to be targeted in the last month in more than three years of similar killings by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GEETA ANAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan Navy Accidentally Fires Antiship Missile, Killing Fisherman
item.description: The supersonic missile, which was set off during a training exercise, hit a fishing boat, killing its captain and injuring three crew members.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: How China Took Center Stage in Bitcoin’s Civil War
item.media:description: Racks of computers at a server farm mining Bitcoin and Ethereum.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Through vast server farms and canny investments, Chinese companies have effectively centralized control over a currency designed to be borderless.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: What in the World: How Do You Say ‘Welcome to Europe’ in Maltese? Check an Arabic Dictionary
item.description: About a third of the words, not to mention the language’s grammar, are derived from the Arabic that was spoken by Muslim settlers of the Mediterranean islands.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: What in the World: In China, Cheese Is Strange, but Pizza Is Hot
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin / Love_Life / Boarding1Now / iStock.com
item.description: Dairy is not part of the mainstream Chinese diet, but one cheese seller’s prospects may improve as fast food, especially pizza, catches on.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: France’s Latest American Import: Mermaid Schools
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; Photos by Jung Hsuan, Valentyna Chukhlyebova/shutterstock
item.description: How would it feel to be Ariel from Disney’s “The Little Mermaid”? Girls who share that fantasy — and some women — are pulling on monofins and finding out.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: 5 Shot Dead in Cafe in Serbia; Ex-Husband Is Arrested
item.media:description: Men cleaning an area outside a cafe in Zitiste, Serbia, where a gunman killed five people early Saturday.
item.description: A man opened fire with an automatic weapon at a crowded cafe, killing his former wife and another woman before he randomly shot at others, the police said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Bangladeshi Troops Move to End Hostage Standoff
item.media:description: Bangladeshi soldiers and security personnel cordoned off an area in a diplomatic zone in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Saturday.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility after gunmen detonated explosives and took a number of people hostage at a restaurant in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK, GEETA ANAND and RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil’s Olympic Catastrophe
item.description: Can Rio pull off the Games with only weeks to go?
item.dc:creator: VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Editorial: How to Revive the Promise of the European Union
item.description: Addressing Europe’s big challenges will require more unity, not less.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Venezuela, Political Prisoners as Pawns
item.media:description: People walk past a mural of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The government of Venezuela is turning political prisoners into hostages by bartering them with other countries.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL LANSBERG-RODRÍGUEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
